key_points: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced plans to establish an independent commission to investigate the Capitol riot on January 6, 2021.
The commission aims to review the facts and causes related to the insurrection and the interference with the peaceful transfer of power.
Pelosi also mentioned supplemental spending to enhance security at the Capitol.
The formation of the commission follows former President Donald Trump’s acquittal in his second Senate impeachment trial.
Senate hearings into the riot are already scheduled, with Pelosi having appointed retired Army Lt. Gen. Russel Honoré to review Capitol security processes.
Bipartisan support is evident for a thorough investigation into the events and circumstances surrounding the riot.
An independent commission would likely require legislation to create, raising concerns about possible partisan divisions and impacts on President Biden's agenda.
Senators from both parties have expressed the need for a complete investigation to prevent future incidents.
The Senate acquitted Trump of "incitement of insurrection" with a bipartisan vote, but he remains a divisive figure within the GOP.
Discussions continue regarding the accountability and future role of Trump and the need for a systemic review to safeguard the democratic process.
